fields.description: Try running a hg build like https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-CRU2/ and give it a parametrised branch - then when running parametrised, give it a branch/tag/commit that doesn't exist. You get a error dialog you can't escape from.
fields.summary: Help, I'm stuck in Bamboo!

fields.description: I cloned https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-CRU to https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-CRU2 and the new plan didn't have the branch param - I had to add it back manually.
fields.summary: Cloned plan lost build variable/parameter

fields.description: Right now, comment popups on build history of a plan are only shown while the mouse is over the comments icon. If you move your mouse to try to hover over the popup, the popup closes. This means that if the comment contains a link, the only way to click on it is to browse into the detailed results for that build, then use the link on the right hand side. It should be possible to click a link in a comment, no matter how that comment is displayed.
fields.summary: Allow clicking on links in comment popups

fields.description: If ServerID doesn't exist the export fails - create an upgrade task to add ServerID to bamboo.cfg.xml file
fields.summary: Create upgrade task to add serverID to bamboo.cfg.xml file

fields.description:
Size of the multi-file artifacts (ie with copy pattern {{\*\*/\*.jar}}) is calculated incorrectly, it is always 4KB. Example
{noformat}
kbrazulewicz@kozlak:~/work/bamboo-agent$ ls -lR /home/kbrazulewicz/work/BAM/bamboo-homes/8085-pgsql-local/artifacts/ATL-TESTA/JOB1/build-00002/JAR
/home/kbrazulewicz/work/BAM/bamboo-homes/8085-pgsql-local/artifacts/ATL-TESTA/JOB1/build-00002/JAR:
total 4
drwxr-xr-x 2 kbrazulewicz users 4096 2011-05-20 16:30 target

/home/kbrazulewicz/work/BAM/bamboo-homes/8085-pgsql-local/artifacts/ATL-TESTA/JOB1/build-00002/JAR/target:
total 168
-rw-r--r-- 1 kbrazulewicz users 170122 2011-05-20 16:30 atlassian-core-4.6.0-SNAPSHOT.jar
{noformat}
fields.summary: Size of the multi-file artifacts is calculated incorrectly

fields.description:

- create Task B,

- create Task C,

fields.description:
When manual stage is waiting for execution - it changes build time statistics.
Sum of job execution should be counted, not chain stop - chain start times.
fields.summary: Build time for statistics should be sum of job times for rerun builds

fields.description:
This sucks: When you create a spot instance request, you get a request id. However, when you query AWS for that id, sometimes it does not exist.
We have to add a pause before we start querying Amazon for spot instance status.
I think the same applies to regular instance requests - instance ids cannot be used right away e.g. for tagging. Instead, you have to wait for some undefined period of time. In case of regular instances, you can at least monitor the instance status - with spot requests, you can't do anything.
fields.summary: Amazon does not return recently created spot instance requests

fields.description:
From SAC:
"We use Mercurial and our project has a sub-repository (in a folder UI\Elegant) which is specified in the .hgsub file. The project is setup correctly, we can get it to any PC, commit, push, pull changes etc.. However, when changes to the sub-repository are made the Bamboo build fails. The hg.exe command appears to work in getting the project to the cache folder, though the sub-repository (UI\Elegant) is missing, but when it then tries to update the working folder (Bamboo\xml-data\build-dir\AIE-DEV-JOB1) it fails saying no working folder is specified for UI\Elegant.

How can we resolve this?
"
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-4674
fields.summary: Bamboo not updating Mercurial sub-repositories when getting source on build server

fields.description: As part of the JAACS work, allow atlassian-user.xml configuration to be chosen at runtime and to take effect without a restart.
fields.summary: Configure the user repository without restarting
Double encoded ampersands in IM messages

fields.description: Currently it is not possible to upgrade Tasks (ie. the .Net Plugin) using the UPM because Bamboo Tasks use Plugins 1.0 with UPM demands 2.0.
fields.summary: Allow Task Plugins to be upgraded using UPM

fields.description:
Bamboo 3.1 has fixes for 64bit Windows support.

If the machine is 64bit but only a 32bit JVM is installed, the installation fails with a dialog suggesting that the JVM may be damaged and that the correct path needs to be set at "EXE4J_JAVA_HOME".

We need to fail with the correct message ("please install a 64bit JVM") informing the correct failure cause.
fields.summary: Windows Installer does not fail gracefully if a 64bit JVM is necessary

fields.description:
It would be nice to have Bamboo variables for current system day, year and month.

Scenario, customer would like to label nightly builds with date and time of execution, while its possible to use Global Variables here (SVN Build number, buildTimeStamp and etc) we don't have any day/year/week/month Bamboo Variables.
fields.summary: Additional Bamboo Variable(s)

fields.description:
Before 3.1 the wallboard was displaying all the failed builds on the top. Version 3.1 started displaying them in the same order as the Dashboard.

Would be good to allow users to define what order they want to display the plans. Alphabetic, failures first or custom order.
fields.summary: Provide More Customization options for the Wallboard
Document use of global variables in post-build labeller plugin

fields.description: The plan summary page sometimes contains an "Error Log" section toward the bottom. The list of errors is not sorted, and includes many old errors. It should only include the most recent, and sorting should be by date descending (or configurable).

fields.description:
While testing Bamboo 3.0 ({{3.0.4-studio-1-SNAPSHOT}}) upgrade in Studio, we noticed that on the elastic instance started using the default image configuration, in the {{/opt/apache-maven-2.0.*9*}} directory, the Maven version 2.0.*10* was installed. ({{apache-maven-2.0.9}} is a symbolic link).
{noformat}
[root@ip-10-112-95-191 opt]# /opt/apache-maven-2.0.9/bin/mvn -version
Maven version: 2.0.10
Java version: 1.6.0_21
OS name: "linux" version: "2.6.21.7-2.fc8xen" arch: "i386" Family: "unix"
{noformat}
fields.summary: Maven 2.0.10 installed to the 2.0.9 directory on the default elastic image

fields.description: If you create a plan, you get sent to the Task config page. Don't save this page and run it. You'll get http://tardigrade.sydney.atlassian.com:8085/bamboo/browse/BPLUG-BED-JOB1-2/log
fields.summary: Import from Maven doesn't pick an Executable Label

fields.description:
Currently, the "checkout unit" and "build unit" are in the {{bamboo-home/xml-data/build-dir/PROJ-PLAN-JOBX}} folder. For a job, the code is located in this folder and all the build happens in it.

Would be useful to allow users to checkout once and use the exact same code in all the builds. This can be used when all the jobs/stages are run in the same agent/machine or when transferring the code to the next stage would be faster than checking the code from he repo.

Currently this can be done by zipping the code and making it available as an artifact to other Jobs/Stages.
fields.summary: Allow one checkout to be made and the same code to be used in all Jobs/Stages

fields.description: It would be really great if we implemented support for commit isolation for Perforce (P4), just like we have for Subversion (SVN) for Bamboo 3.2.
fields.summary: Implement commit isolation for Perforce (P4)

fields.description: It would be really great if we implemented support for commit isolation for Mercurial (Hg), just like we have for Subversion (SVN) for Bamboo 3.2.
fields.summary: Implement commit isolation for Mercurial (Hg)

fields.description: It would be really great if we implemented support for commit isolation for Git, just like we have for Subversion (SVN) for Bamboo 3.2.
fields.summary: Implement commit isolation for Git

fields.description: We have custom.cvs, custom.svn and custom.p4 variables to reference SCM info in the build, but there are no variables for GIT repo.
fields.summary: Provide Git repo information as Bamboo system variables

fields.description: When viewing Bamboo email notifications from Studio (currently running Bamboo 2.6.x), I noticed that the emails do not render in the most user-friendly way.  My main complaint is that the links on the right-hand side (for changesets or artifacts) are broken up with each digit or 1-2 letters on a separate line.  Also, 40% of the width of the email is wasted space in the case of this particular email (see attachment).
fields.summary: Email notifications render strangely on iPhone

fields.description:
When on the Plan Navigator page you are shown your stages and within those stages the Jobs. But default you are also shown the Plan history and durations.
By clicking a Job you then get the job success/failures and durations.
It would be nice to go down another level and click a task to see task success/failures and durations.

It would also be nice to have a graph at job level to summarise some of this information. For example, to show the average timings of all it's tasks, a pie-chart perhaps.

Basically I want to cut my Job's large Task into 20 Tasks and get data on the performance of these in relation to each other. I believe this will help me make the scripts more efficient over time and more easily identify problems with resources allocated to build servers/vms.
fields.summary: Historic Task information on Plan Navigator

fields.description:
Still discussed - Jens is against, Mark and Marek would like to have it.

#Clear statement on result summary page 
## JS: Not required 
## MC - Agreed that icon is a bit much, but would be nice to know that it's been reran. 
## MW - so let's decide - will be marked in description. 
## JS: Let's keep it simple and let the user decide if he wants to leave a comment when it was re-run. Most people will not care. Again, keep in mind that the main use-cases are infrastructure/configuration failures. 
## MW: We scare because we care ;) - I'd like to know if I had to run something multiple  times - worth to see how often.

*Open question - how about the logs? overwrite or append?*
fields.summary: Plans and Jobs executed more than once should be clearly marked in UI

fields.description:
# Only failed stage could be executed again
# If stage passes - execution flows as for regular execution
# Plan and Job results should be marked as executed multiple times - for sure in the database - new multistate enum
## JS: We don't care for our use-case.
## MC - I think we should have this flag. I don't think it'll add much complexity and you probably do want to get an idea of how many builds are failing and needs to be rerun. Lower in priority. 
## MW - will not add almost no complexity. We have to have this flag - even if not planning to display it currently (I think we should).
## JS: It's not about technical complexity... but usability. It will make the remote API more complex as well as the user-interface, for potentially very little benefit. Let's add it when people ask for it and not because we think somebody might use it)   - 
## MW: how  additional info in remote API would make it more complex? It is not about call parameter, but returned result. If you don't want to read some field - just don't. Internally, in Bamboo database -  we SHOULD keep this information anyway. Not as multiple results (that's complex) - but just as a simple field. Then, if we would decide, we want to display it - we will. If not - just don;t use the field.
## JS: Agreed... happy to store the information. But let's not expose it in the UI or REST API for now. 
# Only latest result is stored - previous failed results should be overwritten
# No need for special comment
fields.summary: User can resume failed plan on failed stage

fields.description:
When adding some variables to the plan it would be cool to give a hint how to use them. Especially if some other user would like to run parameterised build he/she could not know the details of the particular variables. So it would be nice to have optional field for describing the variables, like "variable name, variable value, optional variable desciption". This description should be visible when performing manual parameterised build.

Whenever users enter a variable into any of the task fields, it should then also display the description, and the contents of the variable, so that users can confirm that they have referenced the correct variable. This makes a lot more sense for a type-ahead implementation of variables, instead of them being filled in free-form.
fields.summary: Some descriptions for global/plan variables.

fields.description:
Using Run parameterized dialog - should be possible to overwrite stored variables

fields.description:
When trying to run a Mercurial build on OSX, I'm getting the following error message via the Bamboo UI despite the fact that the Mercurial capability seems to be set correctly:

{panel}
Error encountered while triggering manual build: Mercurial not found. Is Mercurial Executable capability properly set in configuration?
Plan 'DEMO-IDE' did not start
{panel}

When looking at the logs, the error seems to be related to some Mercurial libraries that can not be found:

{noformat}
Caused by: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.hg.HgCommandException: command [/usr/local/bin/hg, version, --config, ui.ssh=ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no -o BatchMode=yes] failed. fields.description:
Currently, an instance can be customised by attaching an EBS to it.
Often, this is an overkill - an execution of a couple of lines of code would suffice (e.g. for our MySQL and PostgreSQL EBSes or using Elastic IPs).
We should let the user use a script during image configuration - either inline, transmitted via UserData or downloaded from S3 account used to run the instance (and only from there, since the script will run as root).
fields.summary: 20% Lightweight customisation options for EC2 Instance

fields.description:
We have the depot set as such:
Depot View:
//build:CMESW23-SRN02:RAS:pc_workarea/...@lea_server-rc_8.3.0-8.3.0.39_release 

I verify this works properly by running this command:

p4 sync //build:CMESW23-SRN02:RAS:pc_workarea/...@lea_server-rc_8.3.0-8.3.0.39_release

When I attempt to trigger the build I get this error:
Error encountered while triggering manual build: Could not retrieve changelogs from perforce

This shows up in the logs:
Caused by: com.tek42.perforce.PerforceException: Unable to parse output for change numbers.  Output: Unintelligible revision specification 'lea_server-rc_8.3.0-8.3.0.39_release@281495,@now'.
fields.summary: Bamboo cannot build from perforce label

fields.description:
This is related to: https://atlaseye.atlassian.com/cru/CR-BAM-2974#c50132

- fix implementation of RepositoryIsolationPreBuildAction 
- move (currently deleted) IsolatedLocalRepositoryCleanupAction to bamboo-maven-artifact-sharing-plugin
- add command decorator for maven task (in the bamboo-maven-artifact-sharing-plugin) that would overwrite standard repository isolation setting (Maven2IsolatedLocalRepositoryCommandDecorator will be fixed to honour existing setting of -Dmaven.repo.local)

This should be probably backported to 3.1
fields.summary: Update bamboo-maven-artifact-sharing-plugin to work with Tasks
Grails will check for tests even if there are tests not configured.
NAnt home was not autodetected correctly
Add option to use client side mapping for p4 change detection
Add a way to split a string into multiple commands on ExternalProcessBuilder

fields.description:
Bamboo 3.0 introduced a new location for the Artifacts as well as a new folder naming:
{code}
<bamboo-home-dir>/artifacts/PROJECT-PLAN/JOB1/build-BUILD_NUMBER/
{code}
The BUILD_NUMBER will always have a minimum of 5 digits, having the number completed with zeros when necessary. For instance, for build "42" the number will be "00042".

However, there is no easy way to refer to this path in the Bamboo plan by simply using the Build-Specific variables. Varible ${bamboo.buildNumber} does not contain the zeros.

To allow users to avoid issues with the zeros, would be good to provide a variable with the complete path to the artifact folder of an specific job.

Currently, if the users want to use the path, they need to create a script file that would build the correct path with the zeros.
fields.summary: Create a Build-Specific Variable that would provide the path to the Plan Artifacts folder in the home directory

fields.description:
So we can make it easier to replace params.

See discussion in BAM-8636.
fields.summary: It should be possible to add a key with an empty value for a *global* level variable

fields.description:
Same problem with NAnt that has been reported with MSBuild: BAM-8745 (MSBuild Task is not passing arguments correctly).

Attached a proposed patch that fixed issues for us at least.
fields.summary: NAnt Task is not passing arguments correctly

fields.description:
I need to create a file in project build directory before the build is started.
Now I use the Command task with hand-crafted {{-c 'echo -e "stuff\nstuff" > file.properties'}}, but that is far from being convenient.

Please add a task where I could just type in contents of the file in some text area, specify the path and have such file created by Bamboo every time.

Variable substitution in this file would be a bonus.
fields.summary: Task for creating verbatim file before the build is started

fields.description:
When trying to enable a speakeasy extension, bamboo throws a nullpointer exception (attached).
The user interface doesn't update correctly, but after a refresh the extension is enabled.

Steps:
- clean install of bamboo
- installed speakeasy plugin 0.9.1 from maven repo
- uploaded the chuck noris extension
- trying to enable it
fields.summary: Enable speakeasy extension throws nullpointer exception

fields.summary: Polish Tasks UI according to usability testing feedback

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo logs "running command line:" with the command and arguments being run, however it is not always clear what is the Task/Build that is being used.

For instance, a "Command" task can run a "MSBuild" command and the logs will not present any difference.
fields.summary: Report in the Build Logs what is the type of Task being run
Some Tasks fail on Windows because they exceed the MAX_PATH limit of 260 chars
MSBuild Task is not passing arguments correctly

fields.description: We have a remote agent that is running on OSX. If it times out we have a cron job that will re-establish communication with the host Bamboo instance. Each time this happens the builder options for that remote agent get reset. Not all of the options get reset, but the ones that we previously deleted are added back. The defaults: Bash, Script, etc are the ones that are automatically added. This causes problems because we have certain builds that look for Bash being available, however we do not want it run on the remote agent at all (it does not have the full environment setup that is required).
fields.summary: Default builder options for a remote agent keep resetting if they were previously deleted

fields.description: Adding a private organisation repo from GitHub does not appear when you attempt to Load Repositories
fields.summary: GitHub support only seems to support personal and public organisation repos and not private organisation repos

fields.description:
As part of upgrade testing for Bamboo, we use hot backups of the Bamboo database. 
This means that notifications are fully enabled when we bring the upgraded test instance online. This is not desirable.
To fix this, we'd appreciate an option to disable all notifications via bamboo.sh on Bamboo startup.
This would allow us to carry out testing on the upgraded instance without worrying about notifications being sent between the time the server starts and we get into the GUI to remove the SMTP config. Of course, we wouldn't have to touch the SMTP config if the startup option were there in the first place.
fields.summary: Provide option to disable notifications on Bamboo startup

fields.description:
At present in my organization we take hot backups of Bamboo and use these to test upgrades.
Ideally we'd have time to stop all agents, and shutdown Bamboo before taking a cold backup. Alas, this cannot be done.
Often the agents are running when we startup the test upgrade instance, and start doing jobs we don't want them to do (as production is already running them).
Ideally we'd like a switch that can be passed via bamboo.sh to disable all agents on startup, so that when the upgraded instance is running, no jobs can run until the user starts re-enabling the agents manually.
fields.summary: Allow disabling of agents at Bamboo startup
Configuration support for optional stages

fields.description:
This URL doesn't work:
http://tardigrade.sydney.atlassian.com:8085/bamboo/reports/generateReport.action?reportKey=com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.system.reports%3AnumberOfTests&selectFields=reportKey&buildIds=107675649&selectFields=buildIds&groupByPeriod=AUTO&selectFields=groupByPeriod&dateFilter=None&selectFields=dateFilter&dateFrom=&dateTo=&save=Submit
fields.summary: NPE on opening report "Number of Tests" on Tardigrade

fields.description: Currently it retries forever, this requires manual intervention.
fields.summary: Elastic agent should terminate once it has been unable to send heartbeat for more than heartbeat.timeout minutes

fields.description: Currently it waits forever which requires manual intervention.
fields.summary: Elastic agent should be able to timeout while waiting for tunnel

fields.description:
Splitting builds into jobs/stages provides some coarse-grained information about build progress. But it would be awesome if Bamboo could parse builder output and display more in-depth information during the job execution. For instance it could parse maven output and show which artifact is currently being built and which artifacts are already successfully processed. This could be another level in build -> stage -> job hierarchy. To discuss - should each maven plugin execution be reported as well? With maven 3 enhanced output it's pretty simple.

Of course maven is just an example. For each builder type there should be a possibility to plug-in builder output parser that would be responsible to inform Bamboo which part of the build is currently happening (this should be pretty simple for Ant as well). In the future one might even think about generating execution time statistics per artifact for better estimates.
fields.summary: Fine-grained build progress display based on builder output

fields.description:
The way to reproduce the issue:

* Choose Bitbucket 
* Enter username and password
* Choose URL
* Enter URL and load branches
* Select Repositories option again

= Branches are loaded but not the repositories. Only after clicking the option again, it starts loading the repositories.
fields.summary: Switching back from URL option to repositories does not load repositories for Bitbucket
